name: Mastermind
description: # Introduction Mastermind or Master Mind is a code-breaking game for two players. The modern game with pegs was invented in 1970 by Mordecai Meirowitz, an Israeli postmaster and telecommunications expert. It resembles an earlier pencil and paper game called Bulls and Cows that may date back a century or more. (Source [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mastermind_(board_game))) ![mastermind board](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/adrianeyre/codewars/master/Ruby/Authored/mastermind.jpg) # Rules ~~~if-not:haskell 1. The Mastermind (computer) will select 4 colours. The colours are randomly selected from `["Red", "Blue", "Green", "Orange", "Purple", "Yellow"]`. Colours can be duplicated but there will always be exactly `4`. 2. The Mastermind will return an array back to you. For every correctly positioned colour in the array an element of `"Black"` is returned. For every correct colour but in the wrong position an element of `"White"` will be returned. 3. Passing the correct array will pass the Kata test and return `"WON!"`. 4. Passing an invalid colour will fail the test with the error `"Error: you have given an invalid colour!"`. 5. Passing an invalid array length will fail the test with the error `"Error: you must pass 4 colours!"`. 6. Guessing more than 60 times will fail the test with the error `"Error: you have had more than 60 tries!"`. 7. All colours are capitalised. 8. The return array will be shuffled! ~~~ ~~~if:haskell 1. The Mastermind (computer) will select 4 colours. The colours are randomly selected from `[Red, Blue, Green, Orange, Purple, Yellow]`. Colours can be duplicated. 2. The Mastermind will return a `GuessResult` back to you. * Guessing the correct code will pass the Kata test and return `Won`. * Guessing more than 60 times will return `TooManyGuesses`. * For other guesses, `Result black white` is returned, where `black` is the number of correctly positioned colours and `white` is the number of correct colours in the wrong position. ~~~ # Task ~~~if-not:haskell Your task is to create a method called `mastermind()` that will take an object called `game`. The object has already been preloaded so you do not need to worry about it. Within your method you must pass an array into the game object method `.check()`. This will evoke the object to check your array to see if it is correct. ~~~ ~~~if:haskell Your task is to create the following function ```haskell mastermind :: (Code -> Game GuessResult) -> Game Code ``` where ```haskell type Code = (Color, Color, Color, Color) ``` The resulting type `Game` is a `newtype` that is intended to be constructed using it's `Monad` instance and may take advantage of do-notation. `mastermind` shall be called with a function `check` that takes a code and returns a `Game` action that produces a `GuessResult`. `mastermind` should return a `Game` action with the correct code. ~~~ # Example If the Mastermind selected the following colours ![secret code - red, blue, green, yellow](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/adrianeyre/codewars/master/Ruby/Authored/mastermind1.png) ~~~if-not:haskell Then the array you are trying to solve is `["Red", "Blue", "Green", "Yellow"]` ~~~ ~~~if:haskell Then the code you are trying to solve is `(Red, Blue, Green, Yellow)` ~~~ So you guess with ![guess - red, orange, yellow, orange](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/adrianeyre/codewars/master/Ruby/Authored/mastermind2.png) ~~~if-not:haskell `["Red", "Orange", "Yellow", "Orange"]` Your method would look like this. ~~~ ~~~if:haskell (Red, Orange, Yellow, Orange) Your code would look like this. ~~~ ```ruby def mastermind(game) answer = game.check(["Red", "Orange", "Yellow", "Orange"]) end ``` ```python def mastermind(game): answer = game.check(["Red", "Orange", "Yellow", "Orange"]) ``` ```javascript function mastermind(game){ answer = game.check(["Red", "Orange", "Yellow", "Orange"]); } ``` ```haskell mastermind check = do answer <- check (Red, Orange, Yellow, Orange) ``` ~~~if-not:haskell The element `0 => Red` is at the correct index so `Black` is added to the return array. Element `2 => Yellow` is in the array but at the wrong index position so `White` is added to the return array. The Mastermind would then return `["Black", "White"]` (But not necessarily in that order as the return array is shuffled by the Mastermind). ~~~ ~~~if:haskell The element `Red` is at the correct position. Element `Yellow` is in the secret code but at the wrong position. The Mastermind would then return `Result 1 1`. ~~~ Keep guessing until you pass the correct solution which will pass the Kata. # Check result To check the Masterminds return value ```ruby answer = game.check(["Red", "Orange", "Yellow", "Orange"]) p answer ``` ```python answer = game.check(["Red", "Orange", "Yellow", "Orange"]) print (answer) ``` ```javascript answer = game.check(["Red", "Orange", "Yellow", "Orange"]); console.log(answer); ``` ```haskell import Debug.Trace (traceShowM) mastermind check = do answer <- check (Red, Orange, Yellow, Orange) traceShowM answer ``` Good luck and enjoy! # Kata Series If you enjoyed this, then please try one of my other Katas. Any feedback, translations and grading of beta Katas are greatly appreciated.
